title: How to Turn an Image Black and White Except for One Color (Adobe Photoshop Elements 5.0)

steps.headline: Open the image you want to work with.
steps.description: Make a copy for safekeeping. From the File menu, choose “Save as...”, and give it a name like MyFile_Colorized, or any name that strikes your fancy, and put it in whatever folder suits you best. The default will be the folder the original came from, which is why it’s important to rename the file.

steps.headline: Select the area to remain colorized.
steps.description:
Using the marquee tool, or any combination of selection tools, select the area you want to accent with color. Selecting a rectangle is interesting, but you might want to make more complex selections. Select the entire area to remain colorized using the lasso or polygon lasso tool
Use the "add to" and "remove from" selection options to carve out the parts you don’t want colorized
Adding a one or two pixel "feather" option to the selection will make the color area blend with the non-color naturally. In this example, we’re going to draw a rectangular selection around the eyes.

steps.headline: Flip the selection.
steps.description: From the Select menu, choose Inverse. This switches the selection from the eyes, to everything but the eyes.

steps.headline: Create a new adjustment layer.
steps.description: At the bottom of the In the Layers window, click on the black and white circle icon and select Hue/Saturation. This creates a new Hue/Saturation adjustment layer.

steps.headline: Make it happen!
steps.description: In the Hue/Saturation adjustment window, drag the Saturation slider all the way to the left. As you drag it, notice the entire picture except the eyes starts to fade to black and white until your slider is all the way to the left. If you look at the Layers window, you will see the Hue/Saturation adjustment layer has a white layer mask with a small black rectangle in it. That's where your eyes are, and they're masked from the actions of the Hue/Saturation adjustments.

steps.headline: Your picture is done!
steps.description: Save it and post it to Flickr, or Facebook, or your website.

steps.headline: Open the image you want to work with.
steps.description: As with the first method, make a copy for safekeeping. Follow the same steps outlined above and start fresh.

steps.headline: Create a new adjustment layer.
steps.description: As before, create a new Hue/Saturation layer, only this time do it before selecting anything. You will notice that the picture remains in full color and the Hue/Saturation mask is solid white. Desaturate the colors. Drag the Saturation slider all the way to the left to turn the picture black and white. Because there was no masked areas in the Hue/Saturation mask, everything turned black and white. To get color back into the picture, we're going to have to paint a mask in. For this example, we'll colorize just the lips.

steps.headline: Select the zoom tool.
steps.description: It's located at the top of the Tool palette on the left. With the zoom tool selected, drag across the area you want to zoom in on. This will be necessary for the best control of the brush.

steps.headline: Select the paint brush tool.
steps.description: You can do this by clicking on the brush icon, or by typing B on your keyboard. To bring some color back to her lips, we're going to paint in a mask with the brush. When we masked the eyes in the first method, the mask was solid black. Because of the vibrant color of the photo, though, her lips would look almost clownish on black and white, so we're going to do something a little different.

steps.headline: Click on the Foreground color chip, and set the color to 50% gray:
Paint in the mask.
steps.description: Set your brush to be big enough to make the job go quickly, but small enough that you don't paint in too large an area. In this case, a little overflow is fine. We'll knock it back and clean it up in a moment. An alternate method to make the initial selection is to use the Magic Wand tool (press W on your keyboard) and shift-click until you've selected the entire object. Once it's selected to your satisfaction, make sure the Hue/Saturation layer is the active layer, and press alt-Delete to fill your selection with the foreground color.

steps.headline: Clean up the messy bits.
steps.description: Now that you've painted the lips back in roughly, we'll clean up the edges and make it look good. Flip the foreground and background colors so that the foreground color is white. You can do this by clicking the double arrows, or by pressing X on your keyboard. Carefully brush around the edges of the color parts to clean them up and finalize your image.

steps.headline: Save and complete.
steps.description: Save  your picture for upload, for posterity, or because you have more disk space than you know what to do with. Your picture is done!
